Cardiology.title: Cardiology
Cardiology.definition: The medical specialty dedicated to the study of the heart and blood vessels. Derived from 'kardiā' (heart) and 'logia' (study).
Cardiology.how_it_works: Cardiologists manage the heart's plumbing (hemodynamics) and wiring (electrical system). They use ultrasound and electrical mapping to detect structural or rhythmic failures.
Cardiology.modern_innovations: Artificial Intelligence for ECG interpretation and minimally invasive valve repairs.
Cardiology.fun_fact: A blue whale's heart is the size of a bumper car.

ENT_Otolaryngology.title: ENT (Otolaryngology)
ENT_Otolaryngology.definition: Focuses on the medical and surgical management of the head and neck, specifically sensory organs and breathing passages.
ENT_Otolaryngology.how_it_works: ENTs use precision endoscopy to visualize internal cavities and treat the intersection of respiratory airflow and sensory processing.
ENT_Otolaryngology.modern_innovations: Biological treatments for nasal polyps and 3D-printed ear implants.
ENT_Otolaryngology.fun_fact: Your nose can remember 50,000 different scents.

Ophthalmology.title: Ophthalmology
Ophthalmology.definition: A surgical and medical specialty focused on the eye and its surrounding structures.
Ophthalmology.how_it_works: Ophthalmologists use high-resolution laser scanning (OCT) to map the retina and ultra-precise microsurgery to restore sight.
Ophthalmology.modern_innovations: Gene therapy for inherited blindness and robotic-assisted eye surgery.
Ophthalmology.fun_fact: The eye's lens is quicker than any camera lens.

Gastroenterology.title: Gastroenterology
Gastroenterology.definition: Focused on the digestive system, including the GI tract, liver, and pancreas.
Gastroenterology.how_it_works: Gastroenterologists use endoscopic visualization and chemical analysis to manage nutrient absorption and metabolic function.
Gastroenterology.modern_innovations: AI-assisted colonoscopy for better polyp detection and fecal transplants for recurrent infections.
Gastroenterology.fun_fact: The small intestine is about 20 feet long.

Dermatology.title: Dermatology
Dermatology.definition: The specialty concerning the skin, hair, and nails.
Dermatology.how_it_works: Dermatologists use visual patterns and 'dermoscopy' to identify cellular abnormalities and target them with clinical pharmacology.
Dermatology.modern_innovations: Teledermatology for rapid remote diagnosis and biologics that clear 100% of psoriasis.
Dermatology.fun_fact: Your skin completely replaces itself every 28-30 days.

Urology.title: Urology
Urology.definition: Deals with diseases of the urinary tract (men and women) and the male reproductive system.
Urology.how_it_works: Urologists combine 'plumbing' (clearing obstructions) with advanced oncology and robotic surgical techniques.
Urology.modern_innovations: Robotic surgery (Da Vinci) for precise prostate removal and laser lithotripsy for stones.
Urology.fun_fact: The bladder can stretch to hold about 16 ounces of fluid.

Neurology.title: Neurology
Neurology.definition: The medical specialty focused on the brain and nervous system.
Neurology.how_it_works: Neurologists evaluate the body's 'electrical wiring'. They use neuroimaging and electrophysiology to diagnose miscommunications in the brain.
Neurology.modern_innovations: Brain-computer interfaces and new monoclonal antibodies for Alzheimer's disease.
Neurology.fun_fact: The brain has no pain receptors; brain surgery can be done while you are awake.

General_Surgery.title: General Surgery
General_Surgery.definition: A surgical specialty focusing on abdominal contents and the digestive tract.
General_Surgery.how_it_works: General surgeons are masters of 'Open and Laparoscopic' access. They use small incisions and cameras to remove infection or tumors.
General_Surgery.modern_innovations: Single-incision laparoscopic surgery and fluorescence-guided tumor removal.
General_Surgery.fun_fact: Laparoscopy is often called 'keyhole' surgery because incisions are tiny.

Nephrology.title: Nephrology
Nephrology.definition: The specialty dedicated to kidney function and renal diseases.
Nephrology.how_it_works: Nephrologists act as 'chemical engineers' for the blood, balancing minerals and filtering waste when the kidneys fail.
Nephrology.modern_innovations: Wearable artificial kidneys and xenotransplantation (pig-to-human kidney trials).
Nephrology.fun_fact: Your kidneys filter all your blood about 40 times a day.

Pediatrics.title: Pediatrics
Pediatrics.definition: Medical care of infants, children, and adolescents.
Pediatrics.how_it_works: Pediatricians treat a body in a state of rapid change. They monitor milestones and use age-specific diagnostic logic.
Pediatrics.modern_innovations: Neonatal genetic screening for 100+ conditions and child-friendly medical devices.
Pediatrics.fun_fact: Children have 100 more bones than adults (they fuse later).

Psychiatry.title: Psychiatry
Psychiatry.definition: Focused on diagnosing and treating mental, emotional, and behavioral disorders.
Psychiatry.how_it_works: Psychiatrists balance brain chemistry using pharmacology and integrate behavioral therapy to reprogram thought patterns.
Psychiatry.modern_innovations: Personalized psychiatry using DNA markers and Vagus Nerve Stimulation.
Psychiatry.fun_fact: Your brain uses 20% of your body's total energy despite being 2% of its weight.

Orthopedics.title: Orthopedic Surgery
Orthopedics.definition: The specialty concerned with the skeletal system and musculoskeletal function.
Orthopedics.how_it_works: Orthopedists are the 'structural engineers' of the body. They use mechanical fixation and resurfacing to restore mobility.
Orthopedics.modern_innovations: 3D-printed custom joint implants and stem cell injections for cartilage repair.
Orthopedics.fun_fact: The femur is stronger than concrete.

Endocrinology.title: Endocrinology
Endocrinology.definition: Deals with the endocrine system and hormones.
Endocrinology.how_it_works: Endocrinologists are 'system regulators'. They monitor chemical feedback loops to restore hormonal balance.
Endocrinology.modern_innovations: Closed-loop 'Artificial Pancreas' and new once-weekly weight loss medications.
Endocrinology.fun_fact: Hormones can trigger changes in just a few micro-grams.

Neuro_Surgery.title: Neurosurgery
Neuro_Surgery.definition: Surgical treatment of the nervous system (brain, spine, nerves).
Neuro_Surgery.how_it_works: Neurosurgeons operate on highly sensitive tissue using micro-surgical tools and intraoperative navigation.
Neuro_Surgery.modern_innovations: Gamma Knife (radiation surgery) and laser interstitial thermal therapy for tumors.
Neuro_Surgery.fun_fact: Brain surgery can be painless because the brain itself lacks pain nerves.

Physiotherapy.title: Physiotherapy
Physiotherapy.definition: Helps patients restore and maximize strength, function, and movement.
Physiotherapy.how_it_works: Physiotherapists use 'mechanical medicine'—controlled movement and exercise—to trigger the body's natural healing.
Physiotherapy.modern_innovations: Exoskeletons for spinal cord injury rehab and VR-guided physical therapy.
Physiotherapy.fun_fact: Exercise is the only 'medicine' that has zero negative side effects when prescribed correctly.

Dentistry.title: Dentistry
Dentistry.definition: Professional care of teeth, gums, and the oral cavity.
Dentistry.how_it_works: Dentists focus on the 'gateway' to health, using mechanical removal of decay and bio-compatible reconstructions.
Dentistry.modern_innovations: 3D-printed crowns while you wait and laser-based cavity removal without drills.
Dentistry.fun_fact: Tooth enamel is the hardest substance in your entire body.

Plastic_Surgery.title: Plastic Surgery
Plastic_Surgery.definition: Surgical specialty involving restoration, reconstruction, or alteration of the human body.
Plastic_Surgery.how_it_works: Plastic surgeons are masters of tissue handling, moving skin and muscle (flaps) to restore both form and function.
Plastic_Surgery.modern_innovations: Bio-engineered skin substitutes and hair follicle cloning for restoration.

General_Medicine.title: General Medicine
General_Medicine.definition: Prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of internal diseases in adults.
General_Medicine.how_it_works: Internists are the 'medical detectives'. They look at the whole person to connect dots across different organ systems.
General_Medicine.modern_innovations: Pharmacogenomics (testing which drugs fit your DNA) and AI-assisted diagnosis.
General_Medicine.fun_fact: Internists are often called 'The Doctor's Doctor'.

Gynaecology.title: Gynaecology & Obstetrics
Gynaecology.definition: Focuses on female reproductive health and pregnancy/childbirth.
Gynaecology.how_it_works: OB/GYNs manage health throughout life cycles, using ultrasound and microscopic screening (Pap) to prevent and treat disease.
Gynaecology.modern_innovations: NIPT (Non-invasive fetal DNA testing) and robotic hysterectomy.
Gynaecology.fun_fact: Babies in the womb can taste the flavors of the food their mother eats.

Radiology.title: Radiology
Radiology.definition: Imaging used to diagnose and treat diseases inside the body.
Radiology.how_it_works: Radiologists use magnetic fields, X-rays, and sound waves to peer inside the body without an incision.
Radiology.modern_innovations: AI that identifies strokes or cancers faster than human radiologists and Theranostics (radio-ligands).
when_to_consult: Typically referred by another doctor for scans
Radiology.fun_fact: The first X-ray ever taken was of the inventor's wife's hand (she saw her skeleton).

Oncology.title: Oncology
Oncology.definition: The study and treatment of tumors and cancer.
Oncology.how_it_works: Oncologists use a 'Targeted approach'. They identify the genetic mutations driving a tumor and use drugs to block those specific life-paths.
Oncology.modern_innovations: CAR-T Cell therapy and personalized cancer vaccines.
Oncology.fun_fact: More people are surviving cancer today than at any point in human history.

Pulmonology.title: Pulmonology
Pulmonology.definition: Deals with diseases involving the respiratory system.
Pulmonology.how_it_works: Pulmonologists focus on 'Gas Exchange' efficiency and airway mechanics using flow-rate analysis and pressure sensing.
Pulmonology.modern_innovations: Robotic Bronchoscopy and targeted therapy for Pulmonary Fibrosis.
Pulmonology.fun_fact: Lungs can float on water; they are the only human organs that can.

Rheumatology.title: Rheumatology
Rheumatology.definition: Focused on rheumatic diseases and autoimmune disorders.
Rheumatology.how_it_works: Rheumatologists manage the 'Internal Civil War'. They use biologics to calm the immune system's attack on the body's own tissues.
Rheumatology.modern_innovations: JAK Inhibitors (oral biologics) and precision medicine for Lupus.
Rheumatology.fun_fact: Gout was once known as the 'Disease of Kings' due to its link with rich diets.

Haematology.title: Haematology
Haematology.definition: Study of blood-forming organs and blood disorders.
Haematology.how_it_works: Hematologists analyze the 'Fluid Organ'. They diagnose chemical and cellular defects in oxygen transport and immunity.
Haematology.modern_innovations: CRISPR gene therapy for Sickle Cell and Thalassemia.
Haematology.fun_fact: You have about 6 quarts of blood in your body.

Anesthesiology.title: Anesthesiology
Anesthesiology.definition: Pain relief and care for patients before, during, and after surgery.
Anesthesiology.how_it_works: Anesthesiologists are 'Guardian Angels'. They monitor every vital sign while temporarily suspending consciousness for surgery.
Anesthesiology.modern_innovations: Smart Monitoring (BIS) for brain depth and ultra-low dose spinal blocks.
Anesthesiology.fun_fact: Modern anesthesia only became common in the mid-1800s.

Emergency_Medicine.title: Emergency Medicine
Emergency_Medicine.definition: Immediate treatment of acutely ill or injured patients.
Emergency_Medicine.how_it_works: ER doctors use 'Rapid Triage'. They secure the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) to stabilize the patient during the 'Golden Hour'.
Emergency_Medicine.modern_innovations: Mobile Stroke Units and rapid blood-banking for trauma.
Emergency_Medicine.fun_fact: EM became its own specialty only in the 1960s.

Critical_Care.title: Critical Care (Intensivist)
Critical_Care.definition: Care for patients with life-threatening illness or injury (ICU).
Critical_Care.how_it_works: Intensivists manage complete 'Organ Support'. They use machines to take over for failing lungs, kidneys, or hearts while the body heals.
Critical_Care.modern_innovations: AI-based sepsis predictive alarms and non-invasive cardiac output monitoring.
Critical_Care.fun_fact: The first ICU was created in Copenhagen in 1953.

Bariatric_Surgery.title: Bariatric Surgery
Bariatric_Surgery.definition: Surgical treatment for obesity and associated metabolic diseases.
Bariatric_Surgery.how_it_works: Bariatric surgery causes 'Hormonal Shifts'. It alters the gut's chemical signaling to reduce hunger and improve metabolism.
Bariatric_Surgery.modern_innovations: Scarless surgery and long-acting gastric bypass alternatives.
Bariatric_Surgery.fun_fact: Bariatric surgery can put Type 2 Diabetes into remission within days.

Diabetology.title: Diabetology
Diabetology.definition: Focused on the study and treatment of diabetes mellitus.
Diabetology.how_it_works: Diabetologists manage 'Sugar Homeostasis'. They use real-time tech to match insulin delivery to the body's internal state.
Diabetology.modern_innovations: Artificial Pancreas CLOSED-LOOP systems and semanal GLP-1 shots.
Diabetology.fun_fact: Ancient Egyptians described diabetic symptoms in 1500 BC.

Pathology.title: Pathology
Pathology.definition: The study of the causes and effects of diseases via tissue analysis.
Pathology.how_it_works: Pathologists provide the 'Final Verdict'. They view disease at its most fundamental, cellular level to dictate treatment.
Pathology.modern_innovations: Digital Pathology and Genomic Sequencing of tumors.
when_to_consult: Typically referred after a biopsy is performed
Pathology.fun_fact: 70% of hospital diagnosis relies on pathology.

Kayachikitsa.title: Kayachikitsa (Ayurvedic Internal Medicine)
Kayachikitsa.definition: The foundational branch of Ayurveda dealing with internal medicine and holistic healing of the whole body ('Kaya').
Kayachikitsa.how_it_works: Kayachikitsa focuses on 'Agni' (digestive fire) and 'Dosha' balance. It treats the root cause of systemic disease by correcting metabolic errors through herbs, diet, and lifestyle.
Kayachikitsa.modern_relevance: Directly correlates with modern Internal Medicine but adds a focus on bio-energetics and preventive metabolism.
when_to_consult: Lifestyle diseases like high sugar or BP
Kayachikitsa.fun_fact: In Ayurveda, the gut is considered the 'second brain' and the seat of all health.

Shalya_Tantra.title: Shalya Tantra (Ayurvedic Surgery)
Shalya_Tantra.definition: The branch of Ayurveda dedicated to surgical and para-surgical interventions, pioneered by Sushruta.
Shalya_Tantra.how_it_works: Shalya Tantra uses specialized 'para-surgical' methods like medicated threads (Ksharasutra) and thermal cautery to treat complex conditions without extensive cutting.
Shalya_Tantra.modern_relevance: Kshara Sutra is globally recognized for having lower recurrence rates in fistula treatment than modern surgery.
Shalya_Tantra.fun_fact: Sushruta (600 BC) is recognized by the world as the 'Father of Plastic Surgery' for his nose reconstruction techniques.

Shalakya_Tantra.title: Shalakya Tantra (Ayurvedic ENT & Eye)
Shalakya_Tantra.definition: Specialized branch for diseases above the clavicle (Urdhvajatru), covering eyes, ears, nose, and throat.
Shalakya_Tantra.how_it_works: Uses specialized local therapies (Kriya Kalpas) like eye pooling and nasal drops to deliver medicine directly to the sensory organs.
Shalakya_Tantra.modern_relevance: Highly effective for chronic sinusitis and degenerative eye conditions where modern drops have limited effect.
Shalakya_Tantra.fun_fact: Nasya is considered the 'gateway to the brain' in Ayurveda, directly impacting the pituitary gland.

Agada_Tantra.title: Agada Tantra (Toxicology)
Agada_Tantra.definition: Branch dealing with the diagnosis and management of poisons (natural, artificial, and cumulative).
Agada_Tantra.how_it_works: Focuses on 'Vishahara' (poison-removing) herbs that neutralize toxins at the cellular level and prevent blood contamination.
Agada_Tantra.modern_relevance: Extremely relevant for 'bio-accumulation' of pesticides and heavy metals in the modern food chain.
when_to_consult: Chronic allergies due to food combinations
Agada_Tantra.fun_fact: Ayurveda describes 'Dushi Visha' (latent poison) which stays in the body for years before causing disease.

Prasuti_Tantra.title: Prasuti Tantra (Ayurvedic OB-GYN)
Prasuti_Tantra.definition: Dedicated to women's reproductive health, pregnancy care, and childbirth.
Prasuti_Tantra.how_it_works: Focuses on the 'Artava' (hormonal/reproductive fluid) and preparing the 'Kshetra' (field/uterus) for healthy conception.
Prasuti_Tantra.modern_relevance: Known for 'Garbha Sanskar'—the science of positive prenatal influence on the baby's psychology.
Prasuti_Tantra.fun_fact: Ayurvedic texts describe detailed monthly dietary changes to match fetal development 2500 years ago.

Kaumarabhritya.title: Kaumarabhritya (Ayurvedic Pediatrics)
Kaumarabhritya.definition: The branch concerned with child-care, from neonatal to adolescent stages.
Kaumarabhritya.how_it_works: Emphasizes 'Lehana' (immunity boosters) and the purification of breast milk (Stanya Shodhana) to ensure infant health.
Kaumarabhritya.modern_relevance: Growing global demand for Ayurvedic immunity boosters (Suvarnaprashana) to prevent recurrent child infections.
Kaumarabhritya.fun_fact: Suvarnaprashana is given specifically during 'Pushya Nakshatra' (an auspicious star) for maximum potency.

Panchakarma.title: Panchakarma (Detoxification Therapy)
Panchakarma.definition: The cornerstone of Ayurveda: Five bio-cleansing procedures that remove deep-seated toxins (Ama) from the body.
Panchakarma.how_it_works: Follows a three-step process: Preparation (loosening toxins), Main Action (expulsion), and After-care (rebuilding fire).
Panchakarma.modern_relevance: Scientifically proven to reduce systemic inflammation and lipid peroxides (oxidative stress markers).
when_to_consult: Preparing for a new stage of life
Panchakarma.fun_fact: Panchakarma doesn't just treat the body; it is often described as 'shedding an old skin' for the mind too.

Rasayana.title: Rasayana (Rejuvenation & Anti-aging)
Rasayana.definition: Specialty focusing on longevity, revitalization of tissues, and slowing down the aging process.
Rasayana.how_it_works: Focuses on providing optimum nutrition ('Rasa') to even the smallest cells of the body to prevent premature decay.
Rasayana.modern_relevance: Aligns with 'Geroscience' or the study of biological aging, emphasizing antioxidants and adaptogens.
Rasayana.fun_fact: Rasayana practitioners in ancient times were said to live well over 100 years with full physical vigor.

Vajikarana.title: Vajikarana (Reproductive & Sexual Health)
Vajikarana.definition: The branch of Ayurveda concerned with sexual health, virility, and the quality of progeny.
Vajikarana.how_it_works: Nourishes the 'Shukra Dhatu' (reproductive tissue) which is considered the essence of all other body tissues.
Vajikarana.modern_relevance: Integrates psycho-sexual counseling with natural testosterone/progesterone support.
Vajikarana.fun_fact: Vajikarana comes from 'Vaji' (Horse)—the ultimate symbol of strength and speed in ancient texts.

Svasthavritta.title: Svasthavritta (Preventive & Social Medicine)
Svasthavritta.definition: The science of maintaining the health of a healthy person through daily and seasonal regimens.
Svasthavritta.how_it_works: Uses 'Rhythms' (Dinacharya/Ritucharya) to align the human body with the cycles of nature, preventing disease before it manifests.
Svasthavritta.modern_relevance: Direct precursor to modern 'Lifestyle Medicine' and circadian rhythm research.
Svasthavritta.fun_fact: Ayurveda describes the 'Brahma Muhurta' (4:00 AM - 6:00 AM) as the most potent time for brain productivity.
